sentence: Salesforce.com pulled back yesterday, and one investor has protection in place.
optionMONSTER's Heat Seeker monitoring program detected the purchase of 5,000 January 57.50 puts for $4.43 and the sale of an equal number of January 50 puts for $1.58.
Volume was below open interest at the lower strike, so there are two possible explanations for the activity.
One is that the investor previously owned the 50 puts as protection and rolled the position higher following a rally late last month.
Alternatively, he or she might have opened a new vertical spread that stands to make 163 percent if the cloud-software stock closes at $50 or lower on expiration.
Either way, the trade cost $2.85 and will make money to the downside.

(See our Education section)

CRM fell 2.84 percent to $57.57 yesterday, dropping along with other high-multiple technology companies such as Facebook and Twitter.
The stock is still up more than more than 7 percent in the last month following a better-than-expected earnings report on Aug. 21.
Total option volume in the name was triple the daily average, with puts accounting for a bearish 74 percent of the total.
